title: Prison inmates help battle raging wild fires near San Francisco
text:
The Getty fire burns a hillside next to the 405 freeway in Los Angeles on Monday (Picture: New York Times/Redux/eyevine)

Prison inmates joined more than 1,000 firefighters drafted in to battle the growing wildfires tearing through California.

Thousands of residents have fled their homes and hundreds of thousands more were left without power when it was shut off to prevent further wind-driven blazes breaking out in the bone-dry brushland.

The latest blaze broke out near the renowned Getty Centre arts complex in Los Angeles, prompting more evacuations as the fires destroyed several homes and closed schools and roads.

Among those helping battle the blazes are thought to be hundreds of inmate firefighters – prisoners paid $2 per day with an additional $1 per hour when putting out active fires.

Photos showed teams of inmate firefighters trudging past burnt-out homes and other structures on their way to the next inferno.

Wildfires rip through the Los Angeles hillside (Picture: New York Times/Redux/eyevine)

A wind-driven fire burns a farm structure during the Kincade fire (Picture: Philip Pacheco/AFP via Getty Images)

Thousands have so far been evacuated (Picture: Philip Pacheco/AFP via Getty Images)

An inmate hand crew walks along Wright creek (Picture: Reuters)

California’s governor declared a state-wide emergency earlier this week, with nearly 200,000 people ordered to leave their homes and millions were left without power after the state’s largest utility company cut electricity as a precaution to prevent more areas from igniting.

Among those forced to abandon their homes was LA Lakers star Lebron James, as well as former state governor Arnold Schwarzenegger, who saw the premiere of his latest film ‘Terminator: Dark Fate’ cancelled Monday night.

Other famous faces with homes in the area include rapper and producer Dr Dre and Walt Disney Company CEO Bob Iger.

One wealthy Brentwood resident mused over whether or not he would leave and which of his two cars would be going with him.

The 47-year-old told the Los Angeles Times: ‘I have to figure out what I’m going to do with my Ferrari.’

Man these LA 🔥 aren’t no joke. Had to emergency evacuate my house and I’ve been driving around with my family trying to get rooms. No luck so far! 🤦🏾‍♂️ — LeBron James (@KingJames) October 28, 2019

We evacuated safely at 3:30 this morning. If you are in an evacuation zone, don’t screw around. Get out. Right now I am grateful for the best firefighters in the world, the true action heroes who charge into the danger to protect their fellow Californians. #GettyFire — Arnold (@Schwarzenegger) October 28, 2019

Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E) said early on Tuesday that almost 600,000 more electric customers would have their power shut off as a fire prevention measure ahead of the wind storms.

Almost one million had already seen their sup[ply shut off, although around half of those had it restored by Monday night, the company said.

The so-called Kincade fire scorched more than 74,000 acres, destroyed 123 homes and other structures and was 15 per cent contained as it burned across parts of Sonoma County’s picturesque wine country, state fire officials said.

A sculpture of a horse in the foreground as a wind-driven fire burns a farm structure (Picture: Philip Pacheco/AFP via Getty Images)

Flames burn along Faught Road (Picture: Philip Pacheco/AFP via Getty Images)

More than two million homes were without power after the state’s biggest utility shut it down to prevent further blazes (Picture: Philip Pacheco/AFP via Getty Images)

Over 1,000 firefighters were deployed to battles the blazes (Picture: Philip Pacheco/AFP via Getty Images)

A female inmate firefighter battles the Kincade Fire (Picture: AP)

Inmate firefighters walk past a burnt home on Tigertail road during the Getty Fire (Picture: Apu Gomes/AFP via Getty Images)

They added that the so-called Getty fire covered more than 600 acres in the scrub-covered hills around Interstate 405, near some of the city’s most expensive homes.

It destroyed eight structures and was five per cent contained, officials said.

Los Angeles Fire Chief Ralph Terrazas said his firefighters had told him ‘they were literally overwhelmed’ in the early hours of the blaze.

‘They had to make some tough decisions on which houses they were able to protect,’ he added.
